Yes, sea level rise will continue for millennia, and its rate is dependent on future emissions [p.34][p.46].

Many changes from past and future greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are irreversible on centennial to millennial time scales, particularly for global sea level [p.35]. Sea level rise is projected to continue for thousands of years (high confidence) [p.34]. Over the next 2000 years, global mean sea level is projected to rise by about 2 to 3 m if warming is limited to 1.5°C, and 2 to 6 m if limited to 2°C [p.43]. At sustained warming levels between 2°C and 3°C, the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets are projected to be lost almost completely and irreversibly over multiple millennia (limited evidence) [p.43].

The rate, magnitude, and long-term commitment of sea level rise depend on emissions [p.43]. Higher greenhouse gas emissions lead to larger and faster rates of sea level rise [p.43][p.46]. Global mean sea level will continue to increase in the 21st century at rates that are dependent on future emissions (virtually certain) [p.35].

This dependence is illustrated by projections for different emissions scenarios [p.47]:
* By 2100, relative to 1995–2014, the likely global mean sea level rise is projected to be between 0.28 to 0.55 m under the very low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-1.9) [p.47].
* Under the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5), the likely rise by 2100 is projected to be 0.63 to 1.01 m [p.47].
* By 2150, this divergence increases, with a projected rise of 0.37 to 0.86 m under SSP1-1.9 and 0.98 to 1.88 m under SSP5-8.5 (medium confidence) [p.47].
